snippet: About 8,000 television spots by DraftKings and FanDuel in the N.F.L.’s opening week raised awareness of daily fantasy sports games, but critics still questioned their legality.
abstract: Broadcasts during first week of 2015 NFL games are filled with advertisements by DraftKings and FanDuel, daily fantasy sports-contest services that critics describe as de facto gambling; NFL has distanced itself from daily fantasy games, which differ from season-long fantasy games, and allows owners of pro football teams to have financial stake in companies, stance critics call hypocritical.

byline.original: By JOE DRAPE and KEN BELSON

lead_paragraph: About 8,000 television spots by DraftKings and FanDuel in the N.F.L.’s opening week raised awareness of daily fantasy sports games, but critics still questioned their legality.

headline.main: An Ad Blitz for Fantasy Sports Games, but Some See Plain Old Gambling
headline.print_headline: Sites Don’t Offer ‘Gambling.’ Critics Say That’s a Fantasy.
